item.title: Spanish Living Healthy with Diabetes Workshops
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Spanish Living Healthy with Diabetes Workshops

The Living Healthy with Diabetes (DSMP**) is a 6-week workshop for people with type 2 diabetes. It teaches the skills needed in the day-to-day management of diabetes and to maintain and/or increase life’s activities. This workshop supports participants in developing the skills needed in the day-to-day management of type 2 diabetes. The curriculum supports self-managed behavior modification and coping strategies to enable participants to manage their type 2 diabetes, food choices, medications, and increase physical activity levels.

Spanish Living Healthy with Diabetes Workshop Schedule:

Click on your County to see workshops in the area:

ORANGE COUNTY
OSCEOLA COUNTY 
SEMINOLE COUNTY
BREVARD COUNTY

item.title: Matter of Balance Workshops
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Matter of Balance Workshops

The Matter of Balance “Managing Concerns about Falls” is an 8-session workshop that is either in a 4-week, twice a week or 8-week, once a week form. Each session is 2 hours long and is designed to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity levels among older adults. Participants learn to set realistic goals to increase activity, change their environment to reduce fall risk factors, and learn simple exercises to increase strength and balance.

MATTER OF BALANCE WORKSHOP SCHEDULE

Click on your County to see workshops in the area:

ORANGE COUNTY
OSCEOLA COUNTY 
SEMINOLE COUNTY
BREVARD COUNTY

Senior Resource Alliance (SRA) hosted a Matter of Balance: Managing Concerns About Falls Workshop in October 2015 in which 11 people participated. The Matter of Balance Workshop is an evidence-based falls program which emphasizes practical coping strategies to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity levels. The Participants learn to view falls and fear of falling as controllable, set realistic goals to increase activity and change their environment to reduce the risk factors for falls.  The workshop is conducted over eight sessions and is facilitated by volunteer peer leaders.  One participant in this workshop said “This program has given me confidence and I now realize how important exercise is”, another participant said “Since beginning this workshop, I have more flexibility and I have learned tips to walking up and down stairs with confidence”.

Fall Prevention

Exercise to Improve Your Balance
Having good balance is important for many everyday activities, such as going up an down the stairs.  It also helps you walk safely and avoid tripping and falling over objects in your way.

Preventing Falls
Don’t let a fear of falling keep you from being active.  There are simple ways you can prevent most falls.

National Institute on Aging – Falls and Fractures
If you take care of your overall health, you may be able to lower your chances of falling.  Here are some helpful hints to help avoid falls and broken bones.

Tai Chi Benefits
Many health benefits which can help prevent injury and falls.

The Matter of Balance \u201cManaging Concerns about Falls\u201d is an 8-session workshop that is either in a 4-week, twice a week or 8-week, once a week form. Each session is 2 hours long and is designed to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity levels among older adults. Participants learn to set realistic goals to increase activity, change their environment to reduce fall risk factors, and learn simple exercises to increase strength and balance.<\/h4>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"c78bbd8","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"MATTER OF BALANCE WORKSHOP SCHEDULE","text_color":"#0235D1","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Poppins","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"80526a5","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Senior Resource Alliance (SRA) hosted a\u00a0Matter of Balance: Managing Concerns About Falls Workshop<\/i>\u00a0in October 2015 in which 11 people participated. The Matter of Balance Workshop is an evidence-based falls program which emphasizes practical coping strategies to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity levels. The Participants learn to view falls and fear of falling as controllable, set realistic goals to increase activity and change their environment to reduce the risk factors for falls.\u00a0 The workshop is conducted over eight sessions and is facilitated by volunteer peer leaders.\u00a0 One participant in this workshop said \u201cThis program has given me confidence and I now realize how important exercise is\u201d, another participant said \u201cSince beginning this workshop, I have more flexibility and I have learned tips to walking up and down stairs with confidence\u201d.<\/h4>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"b6e22fe","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":32,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"6ed9bc9","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/01\/mob-class.jpg","id":2692},"caption_source":"custom","caption":"June Preventing Falls
Don\u2019t let a fear of falling keep you from being active.\u00a0 There are simple ways you can prevent most falls.<\/h4>

item.title: Older Floridians Handbook
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Older Floridians Handbook

This online version of the Older Floridians Handbook is intended to be an easy reference source and guide for older Floridians. It contains useful legal and program information on topics of special interest to persons over sixty years of age, but by no means is it limited in value only to older adults. Persons of all ages should find this booklet informative and helpful. 

The material provided is based on the laws and practices of the State of Florida and its agencies, and in some cases, the laws and practices of the federal government. This Handbook cannot answer every question, nor can it replace the advice and counsel of an attorney when needed. Rather, it provides information of a general natural and answers to some of the more common questions that older Floridians often have.

This Handbook deals with laws and programs which often change. Consequently, dollar amounts and other details may change, usually on a yearly basis - particularly, figures used to determine eligibility for various programs and the amounts of benefits the programs provide.

For more advice, or when the Handbook directs you to a particular agency, please refer to the back of this Handbook where you will find a compilation of agencies and organizations that deal with programs and problems which affect older Floridians.

The Florida Justice Institute, Inc. and Carlton Fields make no express or implied warranties or guarantees concerning the contents of this publication. Laws and regulations frequently change. Coverage is as of the date of publication. If needed, you are strongly encouraged to seek the services of a lawyer. A list of places to contact when you need the services of a lawyer but do not know how to find one or cannot afford one is provided in the Reference and Referral Information section toward the end of the Handbook. You are also encouraged to use the useful web site for free legal services for those who financially qualify at www.FloridaLawHelp.org.

View or download the Older Floridian Handbook

item.title: Spanish Matter of Balance Workshops
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Spanish Matter of Balance Workshops

The Matter of Balance “Managing Concerns about Falls” is an 8-session workshop that is either in a 4-week, twice a week or 8-week, once a week form. Each session is 2 hours long and is designed to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity levels among older adults. Participants learn to set realistic goals to increase activity, change their environment to reduce fall risk factors, and learn simple exercises to increase strength and balance.

MATTER OF BALANCE WORKSHOP SCHEDULE

Click on your County to see workshops in the area:

ORANGE COUNTY
OSCEOLA COUNTY 
SEMINOLE COUNTY
BREVARD COUNTY

item.title: Senior Medicare Patrol
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded: Senior Medicare Patrol

item.title: Make a Difference, Volunteer for SHINE
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Make a Difference, Volunteer for SHINE

Do you want to join a winning team? Do you like to help others resolve problems? Are you looking for a volunteer opportunity that enables you to make a real difference in the lives of elders in you community?
If you answered, “yes” to all of these questions, we may have the perfect volunteer position for you!
SHINE already has over 400 volunteers who have knowledge and experience from all walks of life. But, there can never be enough devoted individuals helping elders make informed decisions about their health coverage. SHINE continuously accepts applications for volunteers to provide services to Medicare consumers, their families, and caregivers.

What do SHINE volunteers do?    

SHINE volunteers:

  • Provide information, counseling and assistance;
  • Make educational presentations to community groups;
  • Distribute materials at health fairs, senior fairs & outreach events; and,
  • Assist with general program support.
Volunteer Requirements    

Requirements to become a SHINE volunteer include an interest in working with the senior population; competent computer skills; the ability to use the Internet; as well as successful completion of required training.

Training is provided to individuals who successfully complete an application. Please contact the SHINE Liaison for an application or for more information. Additionally, active volunteers are asked to commit just four hours a week, attend update meetings and refresher training.

Volunteering can be a significant commitment for some individuals. However, the rewards for volunteering with SHINE are plentiful. Since the program’s inception in 1993, SHINE volunteers have assisted nearly a million elders and their caregivers. In addition to saving elders millions of dollars, they have brought peace of mind to people who have had difficulty understanding their health insurance options.

To volunteer in Brevard, Orange, Osceola or Seminole counties, contact Donna Bradford, SHINE Liaison, at (407) 514-1823.

For more information about SHINE volunteer opportunities outside Central Florida, contact the Florida Elder Helpline at 1-800-963-5337. For additional information on the SHINE program, visit us on the Web at

http://www.FloridaSHINE.org/.

","typography_typography":"custom","title_color":"#000000","typography_font_family":"Poppins","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":41,"sizes":[]},"typography_text_transform":"capitalize","typography_line_height":{"unit":"em","size":1.6,"sizes":[]},"typography_letter_spacing":{"unit":"px","size":2,"sizes":[]},"text_shadow_text_shadow_type":"yes","text_shadow_text_shadow":{"horizontal":0,"vertical":0,"blur":0,"color":"rgba(0,0,0,0.3)"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"b27fc4b","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"958dd69","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Do you want to join a winning team? Do you like to help others resolve problems? Are you looking for a volunteer opportunity that enables you to make a real difference in the lives of elders in you community?
If you answered, “yes” to all of these questions, we may have the perfect volunteer position for you!
SHINE already has over 400 volunteers who have knowledge and experience from all walks of life. But, there can never be enough devoted individuals helping elders make informed decisions about their health coverage. SHINE continuously accepts applications for volunteers to provide services to Medicare consumers, their families, and caregivers.

SHINE volunteers:

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"f585c84","elType":"widget","settings":{"icon_list":[{"text":"Provide information, counseling and assistance;","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-chevron-right","library":"fa-solid"},"_id":"e3d2075","link":{"url":"","is_external":"","nofollow":""}},{"text":"Make educational presentations to community groups;","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-chevron-right","library":"fa-solid"},"link":{"url":"","is_external":"","nofollow":""},"_id":"f226b1e"},{"text":"Distribute materials at health fairs, senior fairs & outreach events; and,","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-chevron-right","library":"fa-solid"},"link":{"url":"","is_external":"","nofollow":""},"_id":"9a429a6"},{"text":"Assist with general program support.","selected_icon":{"value":"fas fa-chevron-right","library":"fa-solid"},"link":{"url":"","is_external":"","nofollow":""},"_id":"57fd4bb"}],"icon_typography_typography":"custom","icon_typography_font_family":"Poppins","icon_typography_font_weight":"400"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon-list"},{"id":"7457b74","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"4939138","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"Volunteer Requirements    ","align":"left","text_color":"#4169E1","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Poppins","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":1,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"200","typography_line_height":{"unit":"em","size":9.5,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"2fae92a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Requirements to become a SHINE volunteer include an interest in working with the senior population; competent computer skills; the ability to use the Internet; as well as successful completion of required training.

Training is provided to individuals who successfully complete an application. Please contact the SHINE Liaison for an application or for more information. Additionally, active volunteers are asked to commit just four hours a week, attend update meetings and refresher training.

Volunteering can be a significant commitment for some individuals. However, the rewards for volunteering with SHINE are plentiful. Since the program’s inception in 1993, SHINE volunteers have assisted nearly a million elders and their caregivers. In addition to saving elders millions of dollars, they have brought peace of mind to people who have had difficulty understanding their health insurance options.

To volunteer in Brevard, Orange, Osceola or Seminole counties, contact Donna Bradford, SHINE Liaison, at (407) 514-1823.

For more information about SHINE volunteer opportunities outside Central Florida, contact the Florida Elder Helpline at 1-800-963-5337. For additional information on the SHINE program, visit us on the Web at

item.title: SHINE Training Event for New Volunteers
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
SHINE Training Event for New Volunteers

SHINE Volunteers are Needed    

As a SHINE volunteer, you’ll have the opportunity to perform a variety of functions, including providing information and assistance to Medicare consumers, their families, and caregivers by conducting counseling on Medicare, Medicaid, health insurance, prescription drug plans, and long-term care planning.  SHINE volunteers also deliver educational  presentations in the community and participate in health fairs and outreach events.

Requirements to become a SHINE volunteer include:

  • Interest in working with the senior population;
  • Competent computer skills and the ability to use the Internet;
  • Successful completion of required training.

Active volunteers are also asked to attend update meetings and refresher training. Training is provided to individuals who successfully complete an application.  If you are interested in volunteering or would like more information, please contact:

SHINE Program Liaison covering Brevard, Orange, Osceola, and Seminole County
Contact Donna Bradford at 407/514-1823 or email for upcoming training and volunteer opportunities.

Legal & Financial Providers

LEGAL AIDE PROGRAMS THROUGHOUT CENTRAL FLORIDA

Legal aide programs provide free quality legal advocacy to economically disadvantaged persons in order to improve their quality of life and enhance their self-sufficiency.

Below is a list of legal aide programs in the Central Florida area.

BREVARD COUNTY

Brevard County Legal Aid, Inc.
Phone (321) 631-2500
http://brevardcountylegalaid.org/

Helpline: 866-469-7444

item.title: Calendar & Events
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Calendar & Events

LIVING HEALTHY WITH DIABETES WORKSHOP
January 15, 2020
1:00 pmto3:00 pm

February 13, 2020
9:30 amto12:00 pm
February 19, 2020
1:00 pmto3:00 pm
February 20, 2020
9:30 amto12:00 pm

Senior Resource Alliance (SRA)-Area Agency on Aging of Central Florida is pleased to announce upcoming 6-week Living Healthy with Diabetes Workshop. This workshop is FREE to attend but space is limited so register early. More workshops are being planned every day in your community so I encourage you to contact me regarding those.

Living Healthy with Diabetes* Workshop Schedule:

Wednesdays, January 15 through February 19
1:00 pm – 3:00 pm
College Park Towers, 5200 Eggleston Ave, Orlando, 32810
Please call 407-514-1806 to register.

Thursdays, January 16 through February 20
9:30 am – 12:00 pm
OFP, 810 N Nowell St, Orlando, 32808
Please call 407-514-1806 to register.

 

Please note: Caregivers, spouses and family members are also encouraged to participate in these workshops as well.

If you are interested in attending, you MUST register to attend, so please RSVP by calling 407-514-1806 or living healthy@sraflorida.org.

*The Living Healthy with Diabetes (DSMP**) is a 6-week workshop for people with type 2 diabetes. It teaches the skills needed in the day-to-day management of diabetes and to maintain and/or increase life’s activities. This workshop supports participants in developing the skills needed in the day-to-day management of type 2 diabetes. The curriculum supports self-managed behavior modification and coping strategies to enable participants to manage their type 2 diabetes, food choices, medications, and increase physical activity levels.

[ January 15, 2020; 1:00 pm to 3:00 pm. January 16, 2020; 9:30 am to 12:00 pm. January 22, 2020; 1:00 pm to 3:00 pm. January 23, 2020; 9:30 am to 12:00 pm. January 29, 2020; 1:00 pm to 3:00 pm. These workshops are designed to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity level among older adults.  Participants learn to set realistic goals to increase activity, change their environments to reduce fall risk factors, and learn simple exercises to increase strength and balance.

Thursdays, January 16 through March 5
1:30 – 3:30 pm
Maitland Senior Center, 345 Maitland Ave, Maitland, 32751
Please call 407-514-1806 to register.

 

 

The Matter of Balance “Managing Concerns about Falls” is an 8-session workshop that is either in a 4-week, twice a week or 8-week, once a week form. Each session is 2 hours long and is designed to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity levels among older adults. Participants learn to set realistic goals to increase activity, change their environment to reduce fall risk factors, and learn simple exercises to increase strength and balance.

Senior Resource Alliance (SRA)-Area Agency on Aging of Central Florida is pleased to announce upcoming 6-week Living Healthy with Diabetes Workshop. This workshop is FREE to attend but space is limited so register early. More workshops are being planned every day in your community so I encourage you to contact me regarding those.

Living Healthy with Diabetes* Workshop Schedule:

Wednesdays, January 15 through February 19
1:00 pm – 3:00 pm
College Park Towers, 5200 Eggleston Ave, Orlando, 32810
Please call 407-514-1806 to register.

Thursdays, January 16 through February 20
9:30 am – 12:00 pm
OFP, 810 N Nowell St, Orlando, 32808
Please call 407-514-1806 to register.

 

Please note: Caregivers, spouses and family members are also encouraged to participate in these workshops as well.

If you are interested in attending, you MUST register to attend, so please RSVP by calling 407-514-1806 or living healthy@sraflorida.org.

*The Living Healthy with Diabetes (DSMP**) is a 6-week workshop for people with type 2 diabetes. It teaches the skills needed in the day-to-day management of diabetes and to maintain and/or increase life’s activities. This workshop supports participants in developing the skills needed in the day-to-day management of type 2 diabetes. The curriculum supports self-managed behavior modification and coping strategies to enable participants to manage their type 2 diabetes, food choices, medications, and increase physical activity levels.

These workshops are designed to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity level among older adults.  Participants learn to set realistic goals to increase activity, change their environments to reduce fall risk factors, and learn simple exercises to increase strength and balance.

Thursdays, January 16 through March 5
1:30 – 3:30 pm
Maitland Senior Center, 345 Maitland Ave, Maitland, 32751
Please call 407-514-1806 to register.

 

 

The Matter of Balance “Managing Concerns about Falls” is an 8-session workshop that is either in a 4-week, twice a week or 8-week, once a week form. Each session is 2 hours long and is designed to reduce the fear of falling and increase activity levels among older adults. Participants learn to set realistic goals to increase activity, change their environment to reduce fall risk factors, and learn simple exercises to increase strength and balance.

An updated Consumer Resource Guide is now available. This guide, developed for elders and their families, contains practical health and aging-related information. It also includes contact information for organizations that provide services and support to Florida's elders.

item.title: Beware IRS Telephone Scam
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Scam & Fraud

Beware IRS Telephone Scams

Tax season is underway, and unfortunately that means that phone scam season is also in full swing.  Every year, the Internal Revenue Service sees a surge in scam phone calls to taxpayers, and each year the scammers seem to become more sophisticated and aggressive when targeting us.  According to the IRS, scammers have bilked Americans out of more than $63 million in the past six years.  The Senior Resource Alliance wants to ensure that you’re aware of these scams—and that you know what to do if a scammer tries to contact you.

Most of these scams come in the form of phone calls claiming to be from the IRS.  Potential phone scam victims are often told they owe money that must be paid immediately. Fake “IRS agents” may threaten their victims with arrest, prison, deportation, or other penalties if they don’t pay a bogus tax bill.  When unsuccessful on the first attempt, phone scammers may call back trying a new strategy.  To try to fool their victims, scammers may use fake names and IRS badge numbers.  They may be able to recite the last four digits of our Social Security numbers, or even make it look like the IRS is calling by spoofing the IRS toll-free number on our caller IDs. If they know our email addresses, they may even send bogus IRS emails to their victims to support their phone calls.

While the situation may seem helpless, there are some important facts to keep in mind if you think you may be the target of a potential IRS scam.  First, the IRS will always send taxpayers written notification via U.S. mail—not a phone call, not an email, and not a text message.  The IRS never asks for credit or debit card information or bank account numbers over the phone, and will never demand immediate payment over the phone.  And even if you owe the IRS money, agents will not take enforcement action immediately following a phone conversation.

While it’s important to recognize these scams, it’s equally as important to report them so our friends, families, and neighbors don’t fall victim. If you receive a call from someone claiming to be from the IRS, politely hang up then do one of these two things:

  1.  If you owe taxes—or think you might owe taxes, call the IRS at their phone number: 800-829-1040.  The IRS employee on the phone can help you with your payment issue.
  2. If you know you don’t owe taxes—or if the caller makes threats of arrest, deportation, or something similar, report the call to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration at (800) 366-4484.  You should also contact the Federal Trade Commission and use their “FTC Complaint Assistant” at FTC.gov.

The Senior Resource Alliance has resources and information on how seniors can protect themselves from identity theft and other scams.  Call the Elder Helpline at 1-800-963-5337 to request materials or a presentation on these topics and other forms of financial abuse and fraud.

We can only stop scams like these by recognizing them when they happen and reporting them to the authorities. Let’s all do our part.  They won’t go away!

Submitted by:   Rose Hines, Elder Abuse Prevention Coordinator
                                      Senior Resource Alliance
                                      www.sraflorida.org

Hospice Scam Protecting Seniors From Fraud

Here is a brief recap of some of the top scams targeting seniors:

  • The IRS Phone Scam – Scammers claim that an individual owes back taxes and penalties, and say that unless the person pays immediately, they could be arrested or have their home foreclosed on.
  • Sweepstakes Scam – Fraudsters call or email victims and tell them they’ve won the lottery and just need to pay a fee to collect their winnings.
  • Social Security Scam – Scammers either phone or email consumers, claiming to represent the Social Security Administration and ask consumers for personal information, such as their Social Security number, date of birth or bank account information.
  • Tech Support Scam – Fraudsters pretend they work for a well-known tech company like Microsoft or Dell. They claim the consumer’s computer has been infected with a virus, and then try to get remote access to the computer, as well as access to the victim’s credit card or bank account information so that they can bill them for fixing the alleged problem.
  • Grandparent Scam – Fraudsters pretend to be the victim’s grandchild and claim they need money to get themselves out of an emergency, such as being arrested. Or they may claim to have kidnapped the senior’s grandchild and ask for ransom.
  • Medicare Scam – Scammers pose as Medicare representatives to get seniors to give them their personal information or pay for unnecessary services.
  • Romance Scam – Fraudsters contact seniors through an online dating site or other kinds of social media. Once they’ve struck up a relationship, they ask for money, perhaps to pay for a trip to visit the senior or to cover some kind of emergency, like medical costs.
  

Seniors are encouraged to get educated on what frauds are out there and to remain vigilant at all times. Here are some tips on how to protect yourself and avoid being scammed.

  1. Know who you’re dealing with. Independently verify any information you are provided.
  2. Pay the safest way. You can dispute credit card charges if you never get the goods or services.
  3. Guard your personal information.
  4. Stay safe online. Don’t send sensitive information unless you are sure the website is secure.
  5. Be cautious about unsolicited emails.
  6. Resist pressure. Legitimate companies and charities will be happy to give you time to talk with trusted advisors and make an informed decision.
  7. Don’t believe promises of easy money.
  8. Fully understand the offer.
  9. Check your bank accounts and credit reports regularly.

Consumers who believe fraud has taken place can contact the department’s consumer protection and information hotline by calling 1-800-HELP-FLA (435-7352) or 1-800-FL-AYUDA (352-9832) for Spanish speakers or visit us online at FloridaConsumerHelp.com.

Medicare Fraud

Most of these scams come in the form of phone calls claiming to be from the IRS.\u00a0 Potential phone scam victims are often told they owe money that must be paid immediately. Fake \u201cIRS agents\u201d may threaten their victims with arrest, prison, deportation, or other penalties if they don\u2019t pay a bogus tax bill.\u00a0 When unsuccessful on the first attempt, phone scammers may call back trying a new strategy.\u00a0 To try to fool their victims, scammers may use fake names and IRS badge numbers.\u00a0 They may be able to recite the last four digits of our Social Security numbers, or even make it look like the IRS is calling by spoofing the IRS toll-free number on our caller IDs. If they know our email addresses, they may even send bogus IRS emails to their victims to support their phone calls.<\/p>

While the situation may seem helpless, there are some important facts to keep in mind if you think you may be the target of a potential IRS scam.\u00a0 First, the IRS will always send taxpayers written notification via U.S. mail\u2014not a phone call, not an email, and not a text message.\u00a0 The IRS never asks for credit or debit card information or bank account numbers over the phone, and will never demand immediate payment over the phone.\u00a0 And even if you owe the IRS money, agents will not take enforcement action immediately following a phone conversation.<\/p>

While it\u2019s important to recognize these scams, it\u2019s equally as important to report them so our friends, families, and neighbors don\u2019t fall victim. If you receive a call from someone claiming to be from the IRS, politely hang up then do one of these two things:<\/p>

  1. \u00a0If you owe taxes\u2014or think you might owe taxes, call the IRS at their phone number: 800-829-1040.\u00a0 The IRS employee on the phone can help you with your payment issue.<\/li>
  2. If you know you don\u2019t owe taxes\u2014or if the caller makes threats of arrest, deportation, or something similar, report the call to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration at (800) 366-4484.\u00a0 You should also contact the Federal Trade Commission and use their \u201cFTC Complaint Assistant\u201d at FTC.gov.<\/li><\/ol>

    The Senior Resource Alliance has resources and information on how seniors can protect themselves from identity theft and other scams. \u00a0Call the Elder Helpline at 1-800-963-5337<\/strong>\u00a0to request materials or a presentation on these topics and other forms of financial abuse and fraud.<\/p>

    We can only stop scams like these by recognizing them when they happen and reporting them to the authorities. Let\u2019s all do our part.\u00a0\u00a0They won\u2019t go away!<\/strong><\/p>

    Submitted by:\u00a0\u00a0 Rose Hines, Elder Abuse Prevention Coordinator
    <\/em><\/strong>\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 Senior Resource Alliance
    <\/em><\/strong>\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 www.sraflorida.org<\/em><\/strong><\/p>","_id":"bfd186b"},{"tab_title":"Hospice Scam","tab_content":"","_id":"4e72934"},{"tab_title":"Protecting Seniors From Fraud","tab_content":"

    Here is a brief recap of some of the top scams targeting seniors:<\/strong><\/p>

    • The IRS Phone Scam - Scammers claim that an individual owes back taxes and penalties, and say that unless the person pays immediately, they could be arrested or have their home foreclosed on.<\/li>
    • Sweepstakes Scam - Fraudsters call or email victims and tell them they\u2019ve won the lottery and just need to pay a fee to collect their winnings.<\/li>
    • Social Security Scam - Scammers either phone or email consumers, claiming to represent the Social Security Administration and ask consumers for personal information, such as their Social Security number, date of birth or bank account information.<\/li>
    • Tech Support Scam - Fraudsters pretend they work for a well-known tech company like Microsoft or Dell. They claim the consumer\u2019s computer has been infected with a virus, and then try to get remote access to the computer, as well as access to the victim\u2019s credit card or bank account information so that they can bill them for fixing the alleged problem.<\/li>
    • Grandparent Scam - Fraudsters pretend to be the victim\u2019s grandchild and claim they need money to get themselves out of an emergency, such as being arrested. Or they may claim to have kidnapped the senior\u2019s grandchild and ask for ransom.<\/li>
    • Medicare Scam - Scammers pose as Medicare representatives to get seniors to give them their personal information or pay for unnecessary services.<\/li>
    • Romance Scam - Fraudsters contact seniors through an online dating site or other kinds of social media. Once they\u2019ve struck up a relationship, they ask for money, perhaps to pay for a trip to visit the senior or to cover some kind of emergency, like medical costs.<\/li><\/ul>
      \u00a0<\/div>
      \u00a0<\/div>

      Seniors are encouraged to get educated on what frauds are out there and to remain vigilant at all times. Here are some tips on how to protect yourself and avoid being scammed.<\/strong><\/p>

      1. Know who you\u2019re dealing with. Independently verify any information you are provided.<\/li>
      2. Pay the safest way. You can dispute credit card charges if you never get the goods or services.<\/li>
      3. Guard your personal information.<\/li>
      4. Stay safe online. Don\u2019t send sensitive information unless you are sure the website is secure.<\/li>
      5. Be cautious about unsolicited emails.<\/li>
      6. Resist pressure. Legitimate companies and charities will be happy to give you time to talk with trusted advisors and make an informed decision.<\/li>
      7. Don\u2019t believe promises of easy money.<\/li>
      8. Fully understand the offer.<\/li>
      9. Check your bank accounts and credit reports regularly.<\/li><\/ol>

        Consumers who believe fraud has taken place can contact the department\u2019s consumer protection and information hotline by calling 1-800-HELP-FLA (435-7352) or 1-800-FL-AYUDA (352-9832) for Spanish speakers or visit us online at\u00a0FloridaConsumerHelp.com<\/a>.<\/p>","_id":"cddad53"},{"tab_title":"Medicare Fraud","tab_content":"

item.title: Protecting Seniors From Fraud
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Protecting Seniors from Fraud

Here is a brief recap of some of the top scams targeting seniors:

The IRS Phone Scam

Scammers claim that an individual owes back taxes and penalties, and say that unless the person pays immediately, they could be arrested or have their home foreclosed on.

Sweepstakes Scam

Fraudsters call or email victims and tell them they’ve won the lottery and just need to pay a fee to collect their winnings.

Social Security Scam

Scammers either phone or email consumers, claiming to represent the Social Security Administration and ask consumers for personal information, such as their Social Security number, date of birth or bank account information.

Tech Support Scam

Fraudsters pretend they work for a well-known tech company like Microsoft or Dell. They claim the consumer’s computer has been infected with a virus, and then try to get remote access to the computer, as well as access to the victim’s credit card or bank account information so that they can bill them for fixing the alleged problem.

Grandparent Scam

Fraudsters pretend to be the victim’s grandchild and claim they need money to get themselves out of an emergency, such as being arrested. Or they may claim to have kidnapped the senior’s grandchild and ask for ransom.

Medicare Scam

Scammers pose as Medicare representatives to get seniors to give them their personal information or pay for unnecessary services.

Romance Scam

Fraudsters contact seniors through an online dating site or other kinds of social media. Once they’ve struck up a relationship, they ask for money, perhaps to pay for a trip to visit the senior or to cover some kind of emergency, like medical costs.

Seniors are encouraged to get educated on what frauds are out there and to remain vigilant at all times. Here are some tips on how to protect yourself and avoid being scammed.

  1. Know who you’re dealing with. Independently verify any information you are provided.
  2. Pay the safest way. You can dispute credit card charges if you never get the goods or services.
  3. Guard your personal information.
  4. Stay safe online. Don’t send sensitive information unless you are sure the website is secure.
  5. Be cautious about unsolicited emails.
  6. Resist pressure. Legitimate companies and charities will be happy to give you time to talk with trusted advisors and make an informed decision.
  7. Don’t believe promises of easy money.
  8. Fully understand the offer.
  9. Check your bank accounts and credit reports regularly.

Consumers who believe fraud has taken place can contact the department’s consumer protection and information hotline by calling 1-800-HELP-FLA (435-7352) or 1-800-FL-AYUDA (352-9832) for Spanish speakers or visit us online at FloridaConsumerHelp.com.

item.content:encoded: • PREPARING FOR HURRICANES AND OTHER POSSIBLE DISASTER

item.title: Disaster Preparedness
item.dc:creator: Admin99
item.content:encoded:
Disaster Preparedness

PREPARING FOR HURRICANES AND OTHER POSSIBLE DISASTERS

Severe weather can affect Central Florida. Older adults must prepare for disasters. Make a plan and know where you will go if a storm threatens.

Special Needs Shelters

Older adults, people with disabilities or anyone else requiring assistance and planning to evacuate should go a special-needs shelter. A caregiver and the elder’s pets (in crates) may join the person needing help.

Special-needs shelters provide basic medical care and monitoring. Each county staffs and manages its own shelters. These facilities have no advanced medical equipment or medications. They cannot provide advanced medical care.

SPECIAL NEEDS REGISTRATION PHONE NUMBERS:

Disaster Preparedness Guide – English version,   Spanish version

Be ready for an emergency with this Emergency Kit!

Keep written instructions about your care and take it to the shelter.

This includes:

  • A list of current medications
  • Special dietary needs
  • Oxygen requirements
  • Directions for respiratory equipment and any other
    electric medical equipment on which you depend

When you evacuate take:

  • Your insurance cards–Medicaid, Medicare, supplements
  • A two-week supply of medications
  • Nonprescription medicines, such as
    aspirins, antacids, etc., you may need
  • Extra oxygen tanks, concentrator and nebulizer, if needed
  • A three-day supply of nonperishable food and water
  • Special dietary foods you must eat
  • A manual can/bottle opener
  • A blanket, pillow, folding chair or cot
  • A change of clothing
  • Other special items you may need, such as eyeglasses,
    hearing aids, prosthetic devices, inhalers, thermometer,
    Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) papers, etc.,
  • Your caregiver

Even if you do not plan to evacuate to a special-needs shelter, you should prepare. Talk with your doctor about your plans. If you use oxygen, inform the local power company. Tell your oxygen supplier about your emergency plans.

The above information is a partial list of items needed for emergency shelters, please contact your local Emergency Management office for additional information and requirements, or view the resources below.

Additional Resources:

  • Florida Division of Emergency Management
    This website contains valuable information about how Florida residents and visitors to the state can prepare for disasters and how citizens can become more involved in the community. Links to many resources including advice for elders, assisting pets, road and shelter status, and more.
  • National Weather Service – National Hurricane Center
    Comprehensive information about tropical storm formation and development along with advisories and updates to weather reports by county. Weather radio information
  • State of Florida Department of Elder Affairs Disaster Preparedness Information for Elders
    The Department of Elder Affairs publication — Elder Update Special Edition for the Hurricane Season (pdf) is available along with additional resources
  • National Safety Council – Emergency Preparedness Plan and Checklist
  • Home Emergency & Disaster Safety – Learn more about home preparedness during natural disasters with some of these helpful resources.
  • Pet Disaster Preparedness – Each type of disaster requires different measures to keep your pets safe.
  • Natural Disasters & Severe Weather – Types of Disasters & Weather Emergencies
  • How to Save on Emergency Supplies – Disaster Prep on a Budget
